item.title: Iran Projects Caution After Israeli Strikes Against Hezbollah
item.description: Leaders in Tehran suggested it would be the Lebanese militia that would strike back at Israel after the killing of Hassan Nasrallah and bombings in Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government supporters in Tehran’s Palestine Square mourning the death of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, on Saturday.

item.title: As Austrians Vote, Far Right Awaits Its Biggest Success
item.description: The Freedom Party has made itself the country’s most popular party, with calls to bar asylum seekers. It is poised to come out on top in parliamentary elections for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Christian Bruna/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Herbert Kickl, the leader of the right-wing Austrian Freedom Party, in February.

item.title: Death of Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s Leader, Pushes Mideast Conflict Into New Territory
item.description: His death is a blow to Hezbollah, the militia force and Iranian proxy he led. Whether it will cripple the group, or fuel another cycle of retribution, remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli airstrike on the southern suburbs of Beirut on Friday that killed Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah.

item.title: How Fentanyl Enters the U.S., One American Smuggler at a Time
item.description: Mexican drug cartels are turning thousands of Americans into fentanyl smugglers, sending an army of couriers who can easily cross between both countries.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Robert Gebeloff and Meridith Kohut
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vehicles lining up on the Tijuana side of the border to cross through the San Ysidro port of entry into southern California.

item.title: Nepal Flooding and Landslides Kill Dozens
item.description: Disasters in the small Himalayan nation have become more frequent as the effects of climate change intensify.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Navesh Chitrakar/Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers in Kathmandu taking residents to safety from the overflowing Bagmati River on Saturday.

item.title: Laborer’s Death Brings to Light Italy’s Conflicted Relationship With Migrants
item.description: Italy, an aging country, badly needs migrant labor and immigration, but the government has admitted that the pathways for legal entry are rife with abuse.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Indian community and of unions of agriculture workers in June protesting the death of Satnam Singh in Latina, near Rome.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader, Hassan Nasrallah, Killed by Israeli Strike at 64
item.description: In 32 years in charge of Hezbollah, Mr. Nasrallah built the Iranian-backed militia into an influential regional force and a potent adversary of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, the secretary general of Hezbollah, seen on a screen in Baalbek, Lebanon, in 2018.

item.title: Using Dance to Provoke, Delight and Tell South Africa’s Stories
item.description: Growing up in a Black township, Vusi Mdoyi found a sprinkle of joy under apartheid in a street-dancing style known as pantsula. As a choreographer, he has elevated it into high art, injected with ideas.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Ilan Godfrey
item.media:credit: Ilan Godfrey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vusi Mdoyi, a South African dancer and choreographer with Step Africa at his purpose built home in Katlehong in September. Incorporating a dance studio and creative hub, he hopes it will give opportunities and exposure to formal dance that he did not get as a child.

item.title: Manhunt Underway After South Africa Mass Shooting Leaves 17 Dead
item.description: Most of the victims were women killed in one homestead, according to the police, who have started a manhunt for the gunmen.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: South African Police Services, via Reuters
item.media:description: Police officials on Saturday at one of the shooting scenes, in a photograph released by the South African police.

item.title: Inside the Lebanese Valley Where Israel Is Bombarding Hezbollah
item.description: The Bekaa Valley, a Hezbollah bastion in eastern Lebanon, had mostly been spared over 11 months of war. But The New York Times saw widespread devastation there after intense Israeli airstrikes this week.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man surveys the destruction left by an Israeli airstrike in Baalbek, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Wily Spy Who Risked His Life to Meet North Korea’s Secretive Leader
item.description: Park Chae-so was so successful in infiltrating the North that Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic ruler, once gifted him blueberry wine. So why was the celebrated undercover agent later jailed by South Korea?
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Whenever I visited the North, I knew my life was on the line,” said Park Chae-so, a South Korean spy who met with the then-leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-il.

item.title: U.S.-Led Coalition in Iraq to Wind Down Its Mission
item.description: The United States has 2,500 troops in Iraq who served as a bulwark against attacks by a resurgent Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Thaier Al-Sudani/Reuters
item.media:description: The United States and Iraq said they had agreed to conclude the coalition’s military mission in Iraq “over the next twelve months, and no later than the end of September 2025.”

item.title: Pope Francis Is Met With Anger Over Sexual Abuse on Visit to Belgium
item.description: During a trip to Luxembourg and Belgium, Francis spoke with 15 people who were abused by Roman Catholic clergy.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Medichini/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis met with King Philippe, second from right, and Queen Mathilde of Belgium, left, in Brussels on Friday. He was also met with survivors of church sexual abuse.

item.title: Brontë Sisters Plaque at Westminster Abbey Typo Fixed
item.description: Punctuation delayed, but not denied: A memorial to Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë at Poets’ Corner in the celebrated London church finally gets its accent marks.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A conservator adding the finishing touches to the Brontë sisters’ plaque at Poets’ Corner in Westminster Abbey in London on Thursday.

item.title: As Hezbollah Threat Loomed, Israel Built Up Its Spy Agencies
item.description: After the 2006 war with Hezbollah, Israel invested heavily to intercept the group’s communications and track its commanders in a shadowy war that ultimately led to the killing of the group’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard featured Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon.

item.title: Israeli Military Video Shows Nasrallah Likely Killed by 2,000-Pound Bomb
item.description: A Times analysis of video from the Israeli military shows that at least eight planes it said were used in the attack on Hassan Nasrallah were armed with bunker-buster bombs.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Riley Mellen

item.title: Here’s Who Remains in Hezbollah’s Leadership
item.description: Israel has recently killed several commanders of the Lebanese militia, including its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Aaron Boxerman, Laz Gamio and Lauren Leatherby/The New York Times

item.title: Protesters Mourn Nasrallah’s Death Around the World
item.description: Protesters gathered on Saturday not only in Lebanon, but also in Iran, in the West Bank and elsewhere to mourn his assassination.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning in Palestine Square in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Antônio Delfim Netto, Brazilian Economic Czar, Dies at 96
item.description: He was credited for the high-growth economy during the early years of Brazil’s long military dictatorship. But critics said his policies brought only short-lived gains.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:credit: Antonio Andrade/Keystone/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The longtime Brazilian finance minister Antônio Delfim Netto in about 1970. He was a bundle of contradictions, variously categorized as a technocrat, a neo-capitalist and a promoter of greater state control over the economy.

item.title: Can Hezbollah Recover From the Death of Hassan Nasrallah?
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah’s killing raises questions about whether the group can strike back at Israel. But U.S. officials say it’s too soon to count the group out.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah on a poster in Beirut in 2017.

item.title: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow, 103, Dies; His Tenure Leading UNESCO Was Stormy
item.description: He was the first Black African to head a major international organization, but complaints about his administration led the U.S. and Britain to pull out of it.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Dominique Roger/UNESCO, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow in 1983. He led UNESCO for 13 years while withstanding accusations of mismanagement and nepotism.

item.title: A Decimated Hezbollah Is a Serious Blow for Iran
item.description: How Iran responds to the death of the Lebanese militia’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in an Israeli airstrike will affect the region, and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians gathered early on Saturday in Tehran to show their support for Hezbollah.

item.title: Strike on Hezbollah Leader Suggests Major Strategic Miscalculation
item.description: The militia group seemed content to trade blows with Israel while avoiding a major conflict. A strike that killed its leader proves it miscalculated.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters attending the funeral of Hezbollah fighters in the souther suburbs of Beirut last week.

item.title: Israel Tracked Nasrallah for Months Before Assassination, Officials Say
item.description: The Israeli military decided to strike at the Hezbollah leader because it believed there was only a short window before he disappeared to a different location, three senior Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Beirut early Saturday.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Victims Voice Relief at Its Disarray
item.description: Amid widespread condemnation of Israel’s massive strikes, Syrian communities persecuted by Hezbollah forces voiced cautious, and sometimes exuberant, celebration.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrians gathered in the rebel stronghold of Idlib on Saturday celebrated news of the death of Hassan Nasrallah.

item.title: At Capacity
item.description: If we can’t remember the things we read and watch and even loved, do they still “count”?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Newfoundland and Labrador Promoted on Barrow AFC Jerseys
item.description: The province is sponsoring an obscure professional team in an effort to attract skilled immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Andrew Couldridge/Reuters
item.media:description: Barrow’s players will carry Newfoundland and Labrador’s name on their jerseys for two seasons.

item.title: Israel’s Latest Strikes Present Stark Reality: Even Beirut Isn’t Safe
item.description: “Nobody has any idea what to do,” said one of the many residents who fled the Dahiya, an area near the Lebanese capital where Hezbollah holds sway, amid overnight Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad, Vivian Yee and Jacob Roubai
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of families seeking safety gathered on Martyrs’ Square in Beirut, Lebanon, on Saturday. Some had spent the night there.

item.title: ‘We’re Still Living in Fear’: Escaping the Attacks in Lebanon
item.description: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Lebanon. Khaled Hussein, 20, fled Syria as a child. He describes the bombardment that forced his family to flee again.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel and Meg Felling
item.media:credit: Matthew Cassel for The New York Times

item.title: Israel’s Military Issues More Evacuation Warnings in Southern Beirut
item.description: The military struck targets throughout the night that it said were tied to Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rising in neighborhoods to the south of Beirut after Israeli airstrikes overnight Saturday.

item.title: Israel Bombs Residential Site in Effort to Kill Hezbollah Leader
item.description: The strike came barely an hour after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, delivered a fiery address to the U.N. General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Amro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lebanese army soldiers gather over the rubble of a levelled buildings as people flight the flames, following Israeli air strikes in the Haret Hreik neighbourhood of Beirut’s southern suburbs on on Friday.

item.title: At Least Four Apartment Buildings Were Destroyed by Israeli Strikes, Videos Show
item.description: Visual evidence analyzed by The New York Times shows that nearby buildings were damaged in the attacks, which targeted Hezbollah’s leader. The extent of the destruction is not yet clear.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Devon Lum, Aric Toler, Lauren Leatherby and Bora Erden

item.title: Iran’s Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Holds Emergency Meeting Over Israel’s Attacks in Lebanon
item.description: Israel’s airstrikes south of Beirut flattened several buildings and targeted Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Iranian holding a photo of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, during a rally to support Hezbollah and Palestinians after Friday prayers in Tehran.

item.title: Who Is Hassan Nasrallah, the Leader of Hezbollah?
item.description: In 32 years in charge of Hezbollah, Mr. Nasrallah, 64, has built the Iranian-backed militia into an influential force in Lebanon and a potent adversary of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, the secretary general of Hezbollah, seen on a screen in Baalbek, Lebanon, in 2018.

item.title: WADA Lost Track of Open Doping Cases Before Paris Olympics
item.description: In a fraught meeting in May, top officials at the World Anti-Doping Agency were warned that a computer glitch might allow athletes accused of doping to compete at the Paris Games.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: A database problem identified before the Paris Olympics created the risk that cases of athletes accused of doping violations were not being tracked.

item.title: Israel’s Pager Attacks in Lebanon and the Law on Booby Traps
item.description: After Israel detonated pagers and walkie-talkies in Lebanon, a fierce debate began about whether the attacks violated international law. A U.N. treaty from 1996 offers an answer.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at the funeral for Fatima Abdullah, 9, who was killed by a pager that exploded in her hands on Sept. 17.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Targeting Hezbollah Shake Neighborhood Near Beirut
item.description: Residents described a scene of flattened buildings and destroyed vehicles after Israel unleashed strikes targeting Hezbollah’s leader outside the Lebanese capital.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad, Vivian Yee, Aaron Boxerman, Christiaan Triebert, Aric Toler and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Amro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of Israeli strikes on Friday in Beirut’s suburbs.

item.title: Zelensky Finds Ukraine’s Fortunes Ties to the U.S. Election
item.description: A whirlwind week of top-level meetings failed to alleviate concerns in Kyiv that a Trump presidency could lead to a dramatic shift in American policy.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met Vice President Kamala Harris in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Israel’s New Campaign Against Hezbollah Started With Raid in Syria
item.description: An attack on a secret weapons lab was one of the most daring Israeli operations against the Iranian proxy group in years, covert in name only.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of Israeli strikes on Masyaf, Syria, this month. The area is only about 30 miles from the Lebanese border, which is why, Israeli and American officials say, Hezbollah manufactures weapons there instead of in Iran.

item.title: Israel Likely to Have Enough Weapons for Multiple Conflicts
item.description: Although Israel, like many countries, is highly secretive about its weapons stockpiles, experts believe it could outlast adversaries in offensives on at least two fronts simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Aziz Taher/Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rising over southern Lebanon after Israeli strikes on Monday.

item.title: The Sudden Appeal of the Bulldog Spirit
item.description: Such is the hold the Premier League has on the popular consciousness that enticing a player away from it is seen as a coup.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Violeta Santos Moura/Reuters
item.media:description: Atlético Madrid’s new English prize, Conor Gallagher.

item.title: Deal to Reopen Libya’s Central Bank Eases Fears of Fighting
item.description: A standoff over control of the bank had destabilized the country’s economy and raised the prospect of fresh fighting between Libya’s eastern and western factions.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Islam Al-Atrash
item.media:credit: Mahmud Turkia/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: At a bank in Misrata, in western Libya, in August. The central bank dispute had frozen the banking system for most Libyans.

item.title: Tropical Storm John Hits Mexico for the Second Time This Week
item.description: The storm made landfall again late Friday morning but was dissipating in the evening. At least eight people have died.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Zelensky Meets Trump Amid Fears for Continued U.S. Support for Ukraine
item.description: The session in New York was part of a nearly weeklong U.S. visit by the Ukrainian president in which he has made appeals to both Democrats and Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, second from left, attended a meeting with other world leaders on Wednesday in New York.

item.title: Shigeru Ishiba to Be Next Prime Minister of Japan
item.description: Shigeru Ishiba, a former defense minister known for his plainspoken opinions, will replace Fumio Kishida next week.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Hiro Komae
item.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba after he was selected as the new head of the Liberal Democratic Party in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: A ‘Super Bowl’ Holiday
item.description: In the state of Victoria, you need more than one day to take in all that the A.F.L. Grand Final has to offer.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:credit: Mark Metcalfe/AFL Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The GWS Giants, in orange, playing the Brisbane Lions in the A.F.L. semifinals earlier this month. Brisbane will play the Sydney Swans in the final.

item.title: Myanmar’s Military Asks Rebels to Stop Fighting and Join in Elections
item.description: Though the offer was quickly rejected by several commanders of the opposition forces, it was still seen as a significant development in the three-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Myanmar’s junta chief military leader, Min Aung Hlaing, during a ceremony in Naypyidaw to mark the country’s Armed Forces Day in March.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Mayor’s Adams’s Arraignment
item.description: Plus, control behind K-pop goes public.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Adams speaking yesterday.

item.title: This Is What Can Land You in Jail for Sedition in Hong Kong
item.description: Three men were the first to be convicted under the city’s recently expanded national security law, which has greatly curtailed political speech.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors watching a video of Xi Jinping at the National Security Exhibition in Hong Kong Museum of History in August.

item.title: What to Know About Austria’s General Election and the Far-Right Freedom Party
item.description: Austrians will head to the polls on Sunday to elect a new Parliament, with the Freedom Party in position to potentially form a far-right government for the first time since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Thomas Kronsteiner/Getty Images
item.media:description: Campaign posters for the People’s Party and the Freedom Party in Vienna.

item.title: Pope Punishes 10 Members of Catholic Movement in Peru
item.description: The Vatican expelled 10 members from Sodalitium Christianae Vitae, a group founded in Peru, after investigators reported cases of physical abuse and cultlike control.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Abd/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis during a visit to Peru in 2018. He expelled 10 members of a group called Sodalitium Christianae Vitae after an investigation into allegations of abuse within it.

item.title: Friday Briefing: New York City’s Mayor is Indicted
item.description: Plus, the control behind K-pop goes public.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams of New York speaking outside the mayoral mansion.

item.title: Netanyahu Defiant as World Leaders Press for Israeli-Hezbollah Truce
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to keep striking the Lebanese militants, who began launching rockets across the border almost a year ago in support of their Hamas allies in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Patrick Kingsley, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lebanese forces securing the area after an Israeli strike hit a high-rise building in the densely populated southern suburbs of Beirut on Thursday.

item.title: Sudan’s Army Launches Operation to Retake Khartoum
item.description: The latest outbreak of fighting comes as nations gathered at the U.N. General Assembly called for an end to the war and for aid to be fast-tracked to millions in need.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Sarah Hurtes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rashed Ahmed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Khartoum, Sudan, on Thursday.

item.title: The Global Threat of Antibiotic Resistance
item.description: Health experts, gathering at the U.N., have begun to shift their focus to try to provide access to basic drugs in countries where preventable deaths from infections occur too frequently.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: James Cavallini/BSIP/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a type of bacteria that causes tuberculosis, has become increasingly resistant to antibiotics.

item.title: Finnish Zoo Returning Pandas to China Because of Cost
item.description: Two pandas are heading back to China eight years early amid lower-than-hoped-for visitor numbers at a zoo in rural Finland, and after the pair didn’t produce a cub.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Johanna Lemola
item.media:credit: Roni Rekomaa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pyry feeding on bamboo in his enclosure at the Ahtari Zoo in Finland in 2018.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Another Hezbollah Commander in Beirut
item.description: The Israeli military said the commander, Mohamed Hussein Sarour, was killed in a strike. There was no immediate confirmation from Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene after an Israeli strike hit a high-rise building in southern Beirut on Thursday.

item.title: Cyber Attack Displays ‘Islamophobic’ Message on U.K. Trains, Officials Say
item.description: The British authorities are investigating after commuters at 19 train stations saw an Islamophobic message when they tried to log on to a public Wi-Fi system.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waterloo Station in London was one of several affected by a cybersecurity incident on Wednesday.

item.title: Both Israel and Hezbollah Have Reasons to Reject a Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Hezbollah has repeatedly said it intends to continue fighting until there is a cease-fire in Gaza, while Israel wants the powerful Lebanese militia to pull back permanently from the border.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aryn Baker and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building destroyed by an Israeli attack in Baalbek, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong Editors Sentenced in Landmark Press Freedom Case
item.description: The two journalists for Stand News were convicted in August of conspiracy to publish seditious articles, in a case signaling new limits on press freedom.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Bertha Wang/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Former chief editor of the now-defunct Stand News Chung Pui-kuen, left, and former editor in chief Patrick Lam, leaving the District Court in Hong Kong in 2023.
